name.value: เกมต่อรถไฟ
チケット・トゥ・ライド・アメリカ

item.description:
With elegantly simple gameplay, Ticket to Ride can be learned in under 15 minutes, while providing players with intense strategic and tactical decisions every turn. Players collect cards of various types of train cars they then use to claim railway routes in North America. The longer the routes, the more points they earn. Additional points come to those who fulfill Destination Tickets – goal cards that connect distant cities; and to the player who builds the longest continuous route.

"The rules are simple enough to write on a train ticket – each turn you either draw more cards, claim a route, or get additional Destination Tickets," says Ticket to Ride author, Alan R. Moon. "The tension comes from being forced to balance greed – adding more cards to your hand, and fear – losing a critical route to a competitor."

Ticket to Ride continues in the tradition of Days of Wonder's big format board games featuring high-quality illustrations and components including: an oversize board map of North America, 225 custom-molded train cars, 144 illustrated cards, and wooden scoring markers.

Since its introduction and numerous subsequent awards, Ticket to Ride has become the BoardGameGeek epitome of a "gateway game" -- simple enough to be taught in a few minutes, and with enough action and tension to keep new players involved and in the game for the duration.

Part of the Ticket to Ride series.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

comment.value: Nice at first, but feels empty after a while.
Meh, it's okay. Rating seems about right. Could play again I guess but if I never play it again I wouldn't even miss it.
Incredible how a simple game as this one can be so fun, it just work perfectly the definitive gateway game. I rest my case.
Not very exciting, but strangely addictive trying to complete those routes. Last game I played I was clearly leading and sabotaged myself comprehensively taking 2 more tickets. Doh!

Scales well 2-5 players, beautifully produced, great introductory game. A bit of luck around the ticket draw but this is fine for this length and weight of game (light-middle). An essential purchase for anyone who plays with casual gamers or for serious gamers who occassionally like something lighter. The Europe map provides some variety and the ticket distribution is an improvement but the rest of the new rules detract from the game. The passenger rules in Marklin are excellent but make the game that little bit too long and the board is a bit too biased to completing tickets. I probably prefer the base game particularly now the 1910 cards have been released
Good game. Easy to get non-geeks involved.
10th anniversary ed.

Fun, lighthearted game for 4-5 players. Good flow, decent strategy. Hits a strange note between strategy and luck. For the more part, strategy can win you the game. That is, unless you get the short routes... Or you are cut off... Anyway, that's why it's best for non-gamers and certainly worth a try for gamers too.
Great game to play with non-gamers.

I know this is one of the most popular games that Board game geek can advertise for, but I don't enjoy it nearly as much as the other Euro games on my list. It seems like there is less interactions with people than other Euro games, which is what I find appealing about them.
I love the simplicity yet still has enough strategy to be interesting. Great family game
Great game for variety of people. Awesome "screw you" mechanics and casual enough for non-gamers.
Played this game at least 20 times on the iOS app but I have no desire to ever play it again. I like games with a lot more strategy than this one offers.
was good at the beginning when I was not so into boardgaming. good filler or good to play with new gamers.
We really like the series. Looking forward to stopping off in Calgary ;)
Only played with 2 and it's rubbish. Would like to try with more. With more it's not rubbish. But it's not that good either. Really don't understand the love for this one.
Put this baby in front of folks that only know about checkers and risk and they go crazy. Where can I get this they say. I have played this over 300 times online and still have a great time.
iOS version
I am always up for ticket to ride, just a perfect game.

I have played this one many more times than I've recorded. I think it is a fine gateway game, but I do not find it particularly engaging nor strategic. The value of laying down 5 or 6 link tracks is too high compared to ticket completion, which essentially breaks the game.
Belongs on every game shelf, everywhere.
iOS version...
what to say, its great simple but allows strategy, major addictiveness and great to look at.
Very good game. Not too hard. Not TOO competitive until the end when you're all scavenging for points (unless two players have similar goals ;) ). I'd totally play it again.
Great tension in this game, and easy to learn and explain to newcomers.

Decent, light simple game, but everyone quickly tires of this one. I use the same strategy every time (take the lowest value tickets, hoard cards to play on the biggest tracks) and rarely lose. Why is this game so celebrated?
Own the [boardgame=24439]USA 1910[/boardgame], [boardgame=89848]Alvin & Dexter[/boardgame], [boardgame=106637]Team Asia & Legendary Asia[/boardgame], [boardgame=106645]India & Switzerland[/boardgame], [boardgame=131188]Heart of Africa[/boardgame], [boardgame=147938]Nederland[/boardgame], [boardgame=182078]United Kingdom & Pennsylvania[/boardgame] and [boardgame=13297]Mystery train[/boardgame] expansions.
A family favorite. Untouchable.
Love it. The game is so colorful and charming.
Fun, good gateway that I can play with lots of people, but I want more depth myself. Figure out if the people you are playing with can handle blocking.
I'll play... but only on special occasions. Good game for casual gamers. Much better than monopoly :)
at the kid's home - played it later with the neighbours
A great fun game even for those who dont normally enjoy board games.

Introduced to me by a friend, on xboxlive. Now I can return the favour, by getting him the actual game it was based upon. He got hooked to the xbox version, now he can enjoy it how it was meant to be played.
Great family game
reviewed on my blog.
Nothing speciale. Simple and easy but do not grows with the amount of games.
Absolutely perfect family weight game with room for skill growth. Quick to teacher and I've yet to play with someone who's had a bad time. I think I'll forever love TTR!
Fun game to play with at least 4 players. The game is simple yet well balanced between strategy, timing and chance (cards) to make it fun and enjoyable without being too heavy and long to learn.
Along with Catan, this is one of the evergreen/gateways of modern board games. You place trains on tracks in order to complete your tickets and score points. Simple straightforward game.
Great game, totally addicting
This is a fun game to play on occasion.

Took me forever to finally get a copy of this, and I am glad that I did. I saw the reviews and BGG rating but every time I was close to dropping the cash for it, I would look at the components, look at the theme, and go, "erm, no." Turns out it is a well made game with a tight system that is accessible to nearly everyone no matter what their level of game experience. Moral? Do not judge a book (or game) by it's cover.

simple rules however multiple layers of strategy, beautifull components!
Posojeno Jure
I'm undefeated at this game (from my wife...) But then she beat me (ONCE!) at Nordic Countries. She keeps trying, though. Doesn't matter how many times I win. SHe really likes this game!
It's an okay game, but pretty simple. Niagara makes a much better gate way game in my opinion.
Uninteresting theme, but good mechanics.

There's a few different routes to victory. I like that you can throw in some defensive play as well as the typical offensive play in such games. Light on player interaction and nothing particularly new about the game system but it's delivered in a very appealing package by Days of Wonder. And I love a pleasing train theme.
A fun gateway game, mostly played with my family.

150909 As much as I respect the design, if I'm never playing it or pulling it out to be played....
130929 After TtR Marklin I really do respect the orignal a lot. With the 1910 expansion its a great game it can be played tight and nasty (using the original deck after you've developed a knowledge of the ticket cards) or with all the cards in play you can just play fun and loose. Just an absolutely great gateway and more game.
120910 After playing TtR europe, I've come away with a newfound respect for the elegance of this game. I think it shines when played tight and nasty. Which unfortunately is not the way my girlfriend prefers to play.
100102 may be a bit light for my taste, but one of the first one to bring out if its with non-gamers.

Ticket to Ride is a modern-day classic, deserves to be in most collections as a good intro set-collection game.
Ticket to Ride is a classic along the level of Catan, and I definitely enjoy its simplicity and elegance. It's a very simple mechanic, but the player competition and the unknown aspect of the cards makes it different every time.
Basically, players are competing to build train routes along different colored tracks throughout the United States. They accomplish this by drawing cards of the correct color, then claiming routes by placing their own trains along the route.
You earn points by completing Tickets (preset routes that you draw from the ticket deck), placing routes, and winning the longest connected route, which is similar to the Longest Road in Settlers of Catan.
Overall, I enjoy Ticket to Ride, but I don't feel the need to have it in my collection. It's definitely worth some plays even if you're a hardcore gamer, and the rules can be gone over in about fifteen minutes. This makes Ticket to Ride a great choice for new or reluctant gamers, since it's really easy to have a fun time with it. Personally, I prefer introducing people with [thing=123540][/thing] instead.
great gateway game =)
Light enough for family game night, improved (IMHO) in subsequent versions (Europe, Nordic, Marklin, et al.)

Has risen from a 6 to a 7 after several plays For such a simple game, and one that contains a lot of luck there is quite a bit of turn angst (especially in the endgame), a quality I definitely like in a game. I certainly want to give it more plays. Overall a good game with some flaws. But even with its flaws I always seem to enjoy myself.
BIN: Not for sale/trade
Enjoyed this one. The expansion adds a little more depth to the game.
Own the iPad app. Good port of the board game. Not my favorite, but fun to go to occasionally. Points dinged more out of disinterest than the quality of the game.
Welcome to Euro games 101. If you look at the syllabus, you will see that in this class we will be learning about victory points and competitive strategy... Always a fun game to play!
A great family game. Some element of luck, and still a lot of strategy. Newbies can get a lucky win every now and then, but a good player will win a majority of games.
Great fun when you can round up three or more players, and my go-to game for trying to get non-gamers to play something.
A modern classic.
Great intro game..done way too much of it.

A good, light, fun family game; it is easy to learn, not overly confrontational, has a good dose of luck but still a decent amount of strategy required, looks nice and cool and attractive on the table, and has fun little bits to play with when you're waiting for your turn. I like trains.
Favorite game and looking to buy more maps. the expansion it worth it for the bigger cards alone.

A great family game. Fun and easy to learn and play. A very nice, well-rounded game.
iPhone/iPad app version is sheer awesomeness, a 9+ easily.
It's a light train game... very light. That's about it.
Facil de aprender, rapido de jugar y muy entretenido. Ideal para inicar a profanos del tablero
Play this a bunch when family is around...after your first game it loses it's fun.
Not my favorite game to get out, but once I start playing it, I usually get really into it. It's a simple mechanic that can lead to ruined friendships if you're not careful.

Good game and an all time favorite among pretty much everyone I know, which makes it the best gateway I know. I am a bit bored of it at the moment, but this score may change after getting an expansion (or two).
This was my gateway in to board gaming as a hobby. I owned other games before but they were if we didn't feel like playing magic. This game opened the door to making board games a hobby.

I really enjoy this game! it's a pretty light weight game which really fits the bill some times, everyone who plays it really seems to enjoy it. It's a rummy-type game where you collect cards of the same colors and then claiming routes. The small cards while annoying at first really don't seem to bother me once the game gets going but I still wish they could've just included full sized cards instead of charging you $20 for the 1910 expansion which is basically just full sized cards... None the less, I still really enjoy this game.
The more I play, the less I want to.
Oh how wonderful.
great filler
Great gateway game!
I just don't like this game. The original version is even worse than the Europe-variant.
It's a train game, my wife loves it, I could take it or leave it. But, it does serve as a good starting point for teaching new gamers.

As everyone says, it is a great gateway game. Good production value and fun game play. Less strategy then I prefer though. Bumping this to an 8. Played it with my wife and a couple of bots. Had a blast. :)

Great blend of strategy and card draw chance. Easy for kids and families to learn and play. There are several versions and expansions of this (now) classic board game, so I would suggest starting with the original (United States) map version.
Would definitely recommend to novice and experienced gamers alike!
Must have for any collection. What more needs said, it's a classic in the truest since of the word.
Super passive aggressive game of building around people. This is a very quiet game where people curse at other's success. It's streamlined enough to where the game is still enjoyable though.
Highly recommended for anyone new to the hobby. Suitable choice as a gateway game. Mechanics are simple yet elegant. Rules are easy to learn.

Solid strategy game. Definitely a must have family title.
My 8 year old daughter caught on almost immediately in her first play and even developed deeper strategy in that first game to stab me repeatedly in the back. Great times!
Added to Geeklist
Love the game, though the USA map just doesn't seem to fit the game the best.
got this for my birthday and it's a hit.
Granted it's a light, gateway style game but it is good for what it is.
A very respectable and solid game. Great gateway game but it has been eclipsed by other games in my house.
At first did not seem as interesting as other games, but over time I have appreciated its ability to draw nongamers into playing.
Family friendly game. Easy to learn and fun to play.
I enjoy it because I can play it with anyone. There's a lot of luck involved though.

Beautiful game, great fun, can be easy going or fierce. This game can really turn cutthroat in a heart-beat too. An awesome game that I'm glad to have in my collection. Not as balanced as the Europe version, but a superb gateway game.

item.description:
The game is created from the movie "The Third Man". The story takes place in Vienna after WWII.

In the movie there are famous scenes about finding the culprit in the sewer system. One player is the culprit, the others are the pursuers.

The game has two phases. Phase 1 consists of building the sewerage system with tiles. The players have to draw the sewerage labyrinth on paper.

In phase 2 the culprit has to reach the sewer exit on the other side of the board.

The other players have to find him in the labyrinth before he reaches the exit. The culprit makes his moves by writing them down on paper while the pursuers move their pieces on the board.

link.value: Spies/Secret Agents
Territory Building
Cooperative Play
Dice Rolling
Tile Placement
I and D
Christian Raffeiner

comment.value: I don't remember when exactly I played this game, but I know I was still a kid - maybe 12 or 13 years old. It was tooooons of fun.
A nice game for a small group of players - has tension and sewer-building. I like it!
Don't confuse this with the hasbro game of the same name...I did. Two different pictures of two different games with the same name.
Another thematic "Where's Waldo" game in the sewers.
